abstract.text: ArgoNeuT, a Liquid Argon Time Projection Chamber in the NuMI beamline at Fermilab, has recently collected thousands of neutrino and anti-neutrino events between 0.1 and 10 GeV.

The experiment will, among other things, measure the cross section of the neutrino and anti-neutrino Charged Current Quasi-Elastic interaction and analyze the vertex activity associated with such events.
These topics are discussed along with ArgoNeuT's automated reconstruction software, currently capable of fully reconstructing the muon and finding the event vertex in neutrino interactions.

body_text.text: The LArTPC technique

Liquid Argon Time Projection Chamber (LArTPC) technology [1] provides mm-scale position resolution, calorimetry, three dimensional imaging, and efficient particle identification for neutrino detection and reconstruction.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: In a LArTPC, the interaction products exiting the neutrino vertex ionize argon atoms as they traverse the detector.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: As argon is a noble element, this ionization is free to drift across the medium.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: An electric field is imposed in the detector and the ionization tracks are drifted towards readout wire planes that are oriented with respect to one another at an angle.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: The ionization induces a current on the induction plane and is collected by the collection plane.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: Combining the information from both planes and detecting the events in time allows a three dimensional image of the event with calorimetric information to be obtained.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: Argon, with a relatively large density, short radiation length, and high scintillation yield, is ideal for neutrino detection and event containment.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: A schematic depicting the LArTPC concept for neutrino detection can be seen in Figure 1.
body_text.section: The LArTPC technique

body_text.text: ArgoNeuT
ArgoNeuT (NSF/DOE) sat just upstream of the on-axis MINOS [2] near detector in the NuMI beamline, about 1 km from the target station and 100 m underground at Fermilab (see Figure 2).
body_text.section: ArgoNeuT

body_text.text: The experiment features a 170 L active volume TPC with a fully contained recirculation and purification system.
body_text.section: ArgoNeuT

body_text.text: The main detector characteristics are summarized in Table 1.
body_text.section: ArgoNeuT

body_text.text: ArgoNeuT collected about 1.35E20 protons on target (POT) with the "low energy" NuMI configuration (0.1E20 POT in neutrino mode and 1.25E20 POT in anti-neutrino mode) from September 2009 to February 2010.
body_text.section: ArgoNeuT

body_text.text: Run operations were largely stable and shift-free over the >5 month span.
body_text.section: ArgoNeuT

body_text.text: Along with a Charged Current Quasi-Elastic (CCQE) cross section measurement (one of many potential cross section measurements) ArgoNeuT will be demonstrating the dE/dx and topological-based particle identification capabilities of LArTPCs with a special emphasis on electron/photon differentiation, a vital step toward the realization of a future backgroundfree electron-neutrino appearance search.
body_text.section: ArgoNeuT

body_text.text: ArgoNeuT is also developing reconstruction techniques specific to LArTPCs in collaboration with MicroBooNE [3] and LBNE [4] through the "LArSoft" collaboration and performing research and design for future LArTPCs.
body_text.section: ArgoNeuT

body_text.text: Indeed, ArgoNeuT is one of the key steps in the phased US LArTPC program moving toward construction of a >10 kiloton detector to be used for long-baseline and atmospheric neutrino oscillation physics, a proton decay search, supernova burst and diffuse neutrino detection, and more [5,6,7,8,9,10,11,12,13].

body_text.text: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity
The Charged Current Quasi-Elastic (CCQE) interaction is the most consequential neutrino interaction channel for accelerator-based neutrino oscillation experiments.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: is used to measure the muon-neutrino flux, constraining the expected electron-neutrino flux at the near and far detectors.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Long baseline electron neutrino appearance searches (MINOS [2], T2K [14], NOvA [15], LBNE [4], etc.) all employ a near and far detector in order to minimize neutrino flux uncertainties.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: However, due to the non-zero nearfar detector systematics (i.e. differences between the near and far detector) inherent in all long baseline experiments, cross section assumptions need to be made 1 .
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Knowledge of the neutrino cross section is required even in the case of a near-far configuration.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The simple two particle event topology and dominant cross section in the most relevant energy region makes the CCQE interaction the golden channel for long baseline neutrino oscillation experiments.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Despite being the golden channel, however, the CCQE cross section is known with only 20-30% precision over most energies.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Furthermore, only one (preliminary) measurement of the CCQE cross section on argon has ever been taken (at < E ν >=28 GeV) [16,17].
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The neutrino energy can be reconstructed with the lepton energy and angle with respect to beam axis alone in the case of a CCQE interaction.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: LArTPCs have the added advantage of the ability to reconstruct the proton(s) that come out of the interaction and, with knowledge of the lepton kinematics, fully reconstruct the neutrino energy.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The additional kinematic constraints from the reconstructed proton(s) aid in neutrino energy resolution and background suppression.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The muon and proton(s) are identified unambiguously in a ν µ CCQE event with a combination of dE/dx and range measurements in ArgoNeuT.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The downstream magnetized MINOS near detector is used to sign-select and, with ArgoNeuT, fully reconstruct the muon while the proton(s) (contained >50% of the time) is reconstructed with ArgoNeuT alone.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: CCQE cross section measurements are subject to large systematics coming from final state interaction (FSI) modeling, flux uncertainties, background neutrino charged current pion interaction cross section uncertainties, and more.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Charged current pion events (ν µ p −→ µ − pπ + , ν µ n −→ µ − pπ 0 , or ν µ n −→ µ − nπ + ) can appear "CCQE-like" if the pion is absorbed (e.g. πN → N N ) during an interaction within the nucleus.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: More CCQE backgrounds can come from interactions involving final state neutral particles (neutrons, gammas) that escape detection and/or neutral current events with a final state pion incorrectly identified as a muon that renders the event "CCQE-like".
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: In true CCQE events the nucleon is also subject to various FSI processes including pion production, charge exchange, and elastic and inelastic scattering within the parent nucleus.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Flux-integrated differential cross sections with muon kinematics and cross sections based on post-FSI observable particles only (rather than pre-FSI, which introduces a model dependence in an attempt to track back to the neutrino interaction itself) are now starting to be reported alongside absolute total pre-FSI cross sections [18].
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Recent MiniBooNE [18] and NOMAD [19] CCQE cross section measurements disagree under the relativistic Fermi gas model (Ref. [20] is commonly used) by up to 30% or more, despite using the same nuclear target ( 12 C).
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Surprisingly, the MiniBooNE CCQE cross section measurement (the larger of the two reported cross sections) surpasses the free neutron cross section.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The discrepancy may be due to a CCQE multinucleon channel in which two correlated same-flavor nucleons are ejected [21] and the experiments' varying levels of blindness to low energy protons coming out of the vertex or "vertex activity".
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: The channel may be the result of both short range correlations and 2 body currents between nucleons.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Protons are not considered in the MiniBooNE CCQE measurement and protons with momentum less than ∼300 MeV/c are not reconstructed in the NOMAD analysis.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: MiniBooNE's complete insensitivity to the proton(s) is advantageous in the sense that the extracted cross section measurements do not rely as much on proton FSI modeling uncertainties [18].
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: However, the experiment is unable to measure a possible multinucleon excitation channel.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Most neutrino detectors have a difficult time resolving vertex activity involving short tracks below Cherenkov threshold.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: ArgoNeuT, with its mm-scale resolution, three dimensional imaging, and few-10s of MeV energy threshold, will analyze the kinematics of vertex activity in CCQE interactions in an attempt to understand the multinucleon CCQE channel and final state interactions in general.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Figure 3 shows a CCQE interaction in ArgoNeuT with clear evidence of vertex activity through a set of <100 MeV protons.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: With the help of the downstream magnetized MINOS detector, ArgoNeuT will be able to compare neutrino and anti-neutrino CCQE events in terms of vertex activity.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: A multinucleon channel involving a 2 proton (neutron) final state before final-state-interactions in CCQE neutrino (anti-neutrino) events will be searched for.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Comparing neutrino and anti-neutrino CCQE-like events may provide some sensitivity to this channel.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Event characteristics such as energy deposited in a sphere of cm-scale radius around the vertex, number of protons, and proton kinematics in general and the differences between neutrino and anti-neutrino events in terms of these variables will be studied.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Furthermore, the possibility of separating neutrino and anti-neutrino CCQE events with LArTPCs using vertex activity alone will be investigated.
body_text.section: The CCQE cross section and vertex activity

body_text.text: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex
The initial goals of ArgoNeuT's automated neutrino reconstruction software are to reconstruct the kinematics of the outgoing muon and find the neutrino interaction vertex.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: These steps are the key to beginning a CCQE analysis with ArgoNeuT.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: The muon reconstruction chain proceeds as follows:
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: • Event filter, to remove empty beam spills from the sample.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: • Deconvolution of the TPC and electronics response from the raw TPC-wire data, to produce standardized unipolar signal shapes.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: • Identification of hits above a threshold having a position, width, and projected ionization associated with each particle track.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: • DBSCAN (Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise)-based [22] cluster finding, to group proximal hits together to form clusters and to identify noise hits.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: The vertex finding process takes hits that have been associated with DBSCAN clusters as an input and employs a Harris/Stephens-based [24] algorithm to find the vertex and endpoints in the event.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: The algorithm considers the hits from a geometric point of view only with an implementation based on Ref.
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex
Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: These vertices/endpoints, after being given a "strength", are matched with the endpoints of lines found with the Hough-transform-based line-finding/fitting algorithm to create "strong vertices".
body_text.section: Reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino vertex

body_text.text: An example of the reconstruction and endpoint/vertex finding algorithms at work can be seen in Figure 4.

body_text.text: Conclusion
ArgoNeuT recently completed its >5 month physics run in the NuMI beamline at Fermilab.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The first few thousand low energy neutrino and anti-neutrino events ever detected with a LArTPC are currently being analyzed with a fully automated software capable of reconstructing the muon and finding the neutrino interaction vertex.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Among other channels, ArgoNeuT is investigating the CCQE cross section with a focus on the vertex activity associated with such events.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: With the unique ability to sign-select muons via the downstream MINOS near detector, ArgoNeuT will perform a direct neutrino/anti-neutrino comparison of low energy protons emanating from the interaction site.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: This measurement may be sensitive to a multinucleon excitation channel involving two same-flavor nucleons (protons, in the case of neutrino CCQE).
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: This study will also seek to illuminate the influence of nuclear effects on the absolute and differential CCQE cross sections and on the experimental definition of CCQE itself.
body_text.section: Conclusion
